item.title: Grand Theft Auto VI and Grand Theft Auto Online Could Be Sold Separately; Rockstar Is Targeting Solid 30 FPS on Consoles, According to Former Animator
item.content:encoded:
https://wccftech.com/grand-theft-auto-vi-online-sold-separately-30-fps-target/

Grand Theft Auto VI and Grand Theft Auto Online will be sold separately at launch, with a potential upgrade for the full game available for those who only purchase the online component of the next entry in the Rockstar series, according to rumors circulating online.

On the GTA Forums, known Rockstar leaker Tez2 said that the release of the sixth main entry in the series will coincide with the first time the full package and the online component will be sold separately at launch. According to the leaker, Rockstar Games will have to factor the price of the online component into the total cost of the game, but could benefit from pricing the online standalone lower to provide access to players who cannot afford the full price, who could, eventually, upgrade to the full game including the main story campaign. At the same time, if the online component is priced low, it could help Rockstar Games keep the price of the full experience low, which is something many in the industry wouldn't want to see, as there are expectations that a potential $80 price tag for Grand Theft Auto VI could normalize video game pricing, which hasn't increased much in the past few years despite rising costs.

The rumors of Grand Theft Auto Online possibly being sold separately from the full Grand Theft Auto VI package isn't the only news related to the highly-anticipated game that's come in the past few hours. As reported by GamesRadar, former Rockstar Games animator, Mike York commented on what console players should expect in terms of performance, saying that the developer is likely going to go for a steady 30 FPS, optimizing the game as much as possible to make sure it will never dip below the target. On PlayStation 5 Pro, using the PlayStation Spectral Super Resolution upscaler, the game could hit 60 FPS, according to the former Rockstar developer, but 60 FPS shouldn't be expected on base hardware at launch. From their experience, the former animator is sure Rockstar is going to squeeze as much performance from consoles as possible to make the game run at 30 FPS, and then later optimize for 60 FPS, as the higher framerate is not as important as making the game amazing at 30.

Grand Theft Auto VI launches on PlayStation 5 and Xbox Series X|S later this year. A precise release date has yet to be confirmed.

item.title: Marvel’s Spider-Man 2 PC System Requirements Detailed; RTX 4090 Recommended For Ultimate Ray Tracing, 4K@60FPS
item.content:encoded:
https://wccftech.com/marvels-spider-man-2-pc-system-requirements/

The Marvel's Spider-Man 2 PC system requirements have been confirmed ahead of today's launch, detailing what system configuration the user will need to achieve certain resolution and performance targets.

Unlike some other recent games, the PC version of the second entry in the series developed by Insomniac Games will not require a ray tracing capable GPU to run even at the lowest resolution and frame rate, as old GPUs like the NVIDIA GTX 1650 or AMD Radeon RX 5500 XT will be able to run the game at 720p, 30 frames per second with the very low graphics preset. To enjoy the game at its very best at 4K resolution, 60 frames per second, and Ultimate Ray Tracing, however, an RTX 4090 will be required. Marvel's Spider-Man 2 will launch with plenty of PC-exclusive features, as has been the case for PlayStation PC ports for a while. Among these features are NVIDIA DLSS 3, including Frame Generation and Ray Reconstruction, AMD FSR 3.1, including Frame Generation, and Intel XeSS support, ultra-wide support, increased ray tracing geometry detail setting, and more. Additional information on the game's PC-exclusive features can be found on the official PlayStation blog.

Marvel's Spider-Man 2 is now available on PlayStation 5. The game will launch on PC later today.

item.title: Microsoft Boasts Xbox Records, But Hardware Sales Collapse Drags Gaming Revenue Down
item.content:encoded:
https://wccftech.com/microsoft-boasts-xbox-records-but-hardware-sales-collapse-drags-gaming-revenue-down/

Just yesterday, it was reported that Microsoft ranked as the top games publisher in the world last month. And yet, their second quarter, fiscal year 2025 financial report doesn't exactly paint a rosy picture of the gaming division. Sure, CEO Satya Nadella boasted about a few records for Xbox Cloud Gaming, Game Pass, and successful games like Call of Duty: Black Ops 6 and Indiana Jones and the Great Circle:

We are focused on improving the profitability of the business in order to position it for long-term growth, driven by higher-margin content and platform services. And we are delivering on this plan.

Black Ops 6 was the top-selling game on Xbox and PlayStation this quarter – and saw more players in its launch quarter than any other paid release in franchise history. And we saw rave reviews of Indiana Jones and the Great Circle, which has already been played by more than 4 million people.

We also continue to see strong momentum for Xbox Cloud Gaming, with a record 140 million hours streamed this quarter. All-up, Game Pass set a new quarterly record for revenue and grew its PC subscriber base by over 30%, as we focus on driving fully-paid subscribers across endpoints.

When you look closer at the numbers, though, overall Xbox content and services revenue increased only 2%, albeit Microsoft said that's above expectations thanks to higher-than-estimated performance from Activision Blizzard, chiefly Call of Duty: Black Ops 6. The growth was this small because gaming revenue specifically was down 7%, dragged by the collapse of Xbox hardware revenue (-29%). Microsoft Chief Financial Officer Amy Hood admitted in the earnings call:

In Gaming, revenue decreased 7% (8% in constant currency) as content and services growth continued to be offset by hardware declines.

There is seemingly no end in sight for these Xbox hardware declines, which have been constant for several quarters now. Partly, it might even be due to Microsoft's own multiplatform strategy. Some gamers undoubtedly see no reason to purchase an Xbox when they can get their games not only on PC but also on PlayStation or Nintendo platforms. Microsoft certainly believes the switch toward multiplatform, confirmed yet again by gaming CEO Phil Spencer just a few days ago, will be worth it in the end; for now, however, the struggles continue. Could this lead to the abandonment of Xbox hardware as a whole? At the time being, Microsoft still believes it can turn this around by making its hardware more alluring on its own rather than relying on exclusive games. In a recent interview with Destin Legarie, Phil Spencer stated:

I want us to innovate and make hardware the differentiator. We've got into this space where the differentiation on the hardware has gone down, and it's really been 'locked games' that have become the identity of the hardware. I love when I see handhelds, when I see unique things that hardware manufacturers do. I want our hardware to compete on power and on innovation. So let's have our platform continue to innovate with services and the hardware work that we're doing — whether it's controller, power, or mobility.
